div.head: WG1 was charged with ...

list.item: coordination, building and publication of the ELTeC
providing advice to partners concerning the structuring of ELTeC subcollections
in particular as regards encoding, linguistic annotation and metadata

div.p:
We divided this into three tasks:
defining selection criteria
developing guidelines for data and metadata
creating a workflow for corpus preparation

div.head: WG1 Proposals
div.p: Out initial proposals were presented at the WG1 meeting in Prague, February 2018

They have been reviewed in several ways:
specific proposals/corrections raised via Github
substantial review of sampling issues by WG3
extensive testing of encoding proposals in practice

div.head: Sampling
div.p: Following suggestion of WG3, we divided the proposals document into two papers, one defining the selection criteria we recommend and the other discussing the theory behind this process.

Recommendations (in summary):
aim to represent variety not population, for each of four criteria:
size of work
date of creation
sex of author
endurance ("canonicity") of work

div.head: Encoding scheme
div.p: Following discussion in Prague, we defined three levels of encoding; TEI schemas exist for eltec-0 and eltec-1. Level 2 proposals will be determined by the outcomes of this meeting!

We produced a preliminary set of training materials for a two day Workshop held in Wuerzburg in April. A dozen participants were taken through the process of converting a PDF file to a fully marked up ELTEc text, using Abbyy fine reader and oXygen.

div.head: Workflow
div.p: We first tested our proposals using a sample of texts contributed by volunteers in a variety of formats and languages, which were all converted to ELTeC (with varying degrees of difficulty). The results are still available as the ELTeC Sampler (12 texts)
We defined a procedure for individual researchers to upload their texts to identically structured repositories on Github, one per language:
